summary: This document is an email chain forwarding a news article about Jeffrey Epstein's former cellmate, Nick Tartaglione, who wrote a letter to the Daily News denying he harmed Epstein. It details the circumstances of Epstein's first suicide attempt while sharing a cell with Tartaglione, the subsequent investigation into Epstein's death, and Tartaglione's own legal troubles.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier and accused sex trafficker who was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019. The document discusses his first suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, while sharing a cell with Nick Tartaglione.

persons.name: Nick Tartaglione
persons.role: Epstein's former cellmate, accused murderer, former police officer
persons.context: A former Briarcliff Manor cop facing the death penalty for quadruple murder. He was Epstein's cellmate at MCC and wrote a letter insisting he never harmed Epstein. He claims he alerted staff to Epstein's first suicide attempt.

persons.name: Stephen Rex Brown
persons.context: Author of the NY Daily News article that is the subject of the email chain.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who stated at a hearing that they did not see a 'despairing or despondent person' around the time of Epstein's death.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Tartaglione's defense attorney. He states his client has not been interviewed by investigators since Epstein's death and criticizes the investigation. He also discusses Tartaglione's request for a transfer from MCC.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney General who stated that 'irregularities' have been uncovered at the MCC following Epstein's death.

persons.name: Martin Luna
persons.context: One of the four men Nick Tartaglione is charged with killing in April 2016.

persons.name: Hector Santiago
persons.context: One of the four men Nick Tartaglione is charged with killing in April 2016.

persons.name: Miguel Luna
persons.context: One of the four men Nick Tartaglione is charged with killing in April 2016.

persons.name: Hector Gutierrez
persons.context: One of the four men Nick Tartaglione is charged with killing in April 2016.

connections.description: Tartaglione was Epstein's cellmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) at the time of Epstein's first suicide attempt on July 23, 2019.
Bruce Barket is the defense attorney representing Nick Tartaglione in his murder case and regarding matters related to his incarceration and the Epstein investigation.
Reid Weingarten was an attorney for Jeffrey Epstein, representing him in his sex trafficking case and speaking on his behalf after his death.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted to hang himself in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) while sharing it with cellmate Nick Tartaglione. Tartaglione claims he alerted jail staff.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at MCC, having hanged himself. He was alone in his cell at the time.

events.title: Quadruple Homicide
events.description: Four men (Martin Luna, Hector Santiago, Miguel Luna, Hector Gutierrez) were killed. Nick Tartaglione is charged with their murders and conspiring to distribute cocaine. Their bodies were found on his farm.

events.title: Tartaglione's Letter Published
events.description: The NY Daily News publishes an article containing a letter from Nick Tartaglione in which he denies harming Jeffrey Epstein and discusses the conditions at MCC.

keyFacts: Nick Tartaglione, Epstein's former cellmate, wrote a letter insisting 'I never touched the man' and claims he alerted staff to Epstein's first suicide attempt on July 23, 2019.
Epstein's first suicide attempt occurred while he was sharing a cell with Tartaglione at the MCC. He was later moved to suicide watch and then back to a single cell where he died on August 10.
Tartaglione's attorney, Bruce Barket, states his client has not been interviewed by law enforcement since Epstein's death, questioning the completeness of the investigation.
Attorney General William Barr stated that 'irregularities' were uncovered at the MCC, and jail staff were reportedly exhausted and failed to follow protocol at the time of Epstein's death.
Nick Tartaglione is a former police officer facing the death penalty for a 2016 quadruple murder and drug conspiracy; the victims' bodies were found on his animal rescue farm.
